cluster_classes.class_description: Steels prone to graphitization, including carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels, which lose strength and ductility due to microstructural changes.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Graphitization affects carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels.

members.entity_description: Steels that do not have alloying elements intentionally added, but may contain small amounts of elements and are affected by graphitization under certain conditions.
A type of steel that undergoes graphitization at elevated temperatures.
A type of steel susceptible to graphitization, especially with up to 1% Mo.
Steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

cluster_classes.class_description: Steels engineered for high-temperature environments, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, valued for strength and creep resistance and relevant to graphitization phenomena.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

members.entity_description: A type of steel used for thick wall reactor vessels in petroleum refinery processes.

cluster_classes.class_description: The area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.

members.entity_description: The portion of the base metal adjacent to a weld with altered microstructure and properties due to welding heat.

args.new_description: Steels prone to graphitization, including carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels, which lose strength and ductility due to microstructural changes.
args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Current Class_Group is too narrow; broadening to 'Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena' better connects related classes and allows for future expansion.

args.new_description: Steels engineered for high-temperature environments, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, valued for strength and creep resistance and relevant to graphitization phenomena.
args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group should match that of 'Graphitization-Susceptible Steels' as both classes cover overlapping steel types and metallurgical phenomena at high temperature.

splits.name: Low Alloy Steels (General)
splits.description: Low alloy steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance, not specifically defined by graphitization susceptibility.

args.justification: Entity 'low alloy steel' (En_7ecdae42) is a broad category not always graphitization-susceptible; splitting it out clarifies the distinction between general low alloy steels and those specifically prone to graphitization.

args.new_description: Low alloy steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance, not specifically defined by graphitization susceptibility.
args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Assigning the new split class to the same Class_Group for schema coherence.

args.new_description: The area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.
args.justification: Class_Group is appropriate and distinct from the steel material classes; no merge or reassignment needed.
